critique: This executive order extends the Federal Aviation Act of 1958 to the Ryukyu Islands, granting the Civil Aeronautics Board (CAB) economic regulatory authority over civil air transportation involving the islands. It also extends Title VII of the Act to the Ryukyu Islands for all purposes. The High Commissioner of the Ryukyu Islands retains control and regulation of aviation within the islands, except as provided in Sections 2 and 3, and the CAB and the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency are to provide technical advice and assistance to the High Commissioner. The order removes the Ryukyu Islands from the applicability of Executive Order No. 10854 of November 27, 1959. This order seems to be primarily focused on economic regulation and federalism. There is a slight increase in federal control due to the extension of the Federal Aviation Act. There is no clear indication of ideological tilt, immigration approach, national security vs. civil liberties, or social inclusion. The executive power is neutral, as it is simply implementing existing legislation.
